verses.text: Through desire a man, having separated himself, seeketh \add And\add* intermeddleth with all wisdom.
A fool hath no delight in understanding, But that his heart may discover itself.
When the wicked cometh, \add then\add* cometh also contempt, And with ignominy reproach.
The words of a man’s mouth \add are as\add* deep waters, \add And\add* the wellspring of wisdom \add as\add* a flowing brook.
\add It is\add* not good to accept the person of the wicked, To overthrow the righteous in judgment.
A fool’s lips enter into contention, And his mouth calleth for strokes.
A fool’s mouth \add is\add* his destruction, And his lips \add are\add* the snare of his soul.
The words of a talebearer \add are\add* as wounds, And they go down \add into\add* the innermost parts of the belly.
He also that is slothful in his work \add Is\add* brother to him that is a great waster.
The name of the \sc Lord\sc* \add is\add* a strong tower: The righteous runneth into it, and is safe.
The rich \add man’s\add* wealth \add is\add* his strong city, And as a high wall in his own conceit.
Before destruction the heart of man is haughty, And before honour \add is\add* humility.
He that answereth a matter before he heareth \add it\add*, It \add is\add* folly and shame unto him.
The spirit of a man will sustain his infirmity; But a wounded spirit who can bear?
The heart of the prudent getteth knowledge; And the ear of the wise seeketh knowledge.
A man’s gift maketh room for him, And bringeth him before great \add men\add*.
\add He that is\add* first in his own cause \add seemeth\add* just; But his neighbour cometh and searcheth him.
The lot causeth contentions to cease, And parteth between the mighty.
A brother offended \add is harder to be won\add* than a strong city: And \add their\add* contentions \add are\add* like the bars of a castle.
A man’s belly shall be satisfied with the fruit of his mouth; \add And with\add* the increase of his lips shall he be filled.
Death and life \add are\add* in the power of the tongue: And they that love it shall eat the fruit thereof.
\add Whoso\add* findeth a wife findeth a good \add thing\add*, And obtaineth favour of the \sc Lord\sc*.
The poor useth intreaties; But the rich answereth roughly.
A man that hath friends must shew himself friendly: And there is a friend \add that\add* sticketh closer than a brother.
